posts.name: kuzey
posts.cooked:
We just assembled our elevator and while we were testing it we found out that our policord system became loose as the elevator moved upwards and tightened as it moved down. below is a video ( sorry for the censor im not allowed to post the whole robot). Please take attention to the left corner of the video. Also a photo i drew of the clamping blocks that clamp the polycord is attached (again sorry for my bad drawing skills) any help would be greatly appreciated!

copy_6D264277-E252-4A46-9DBB-38D1ACB8C90B.mov - Google Drive (video link) IMG_8852 1536×2274 1010 KB

IMG_8852 1536×2274 1010 KB

IMG_8852 1536×2274 1010 KB

posts.name: Mike Schreiber
posts.cooked:
Does the system start under tension? Based on how you have it clamped it doesn’t look like you’re actively tensioning,  just relying on it being cut to the right length?

Polycord is not a material I’ve seen used much for elevator driving, likely because it stretches a lot. Stretch is very bad in this application because it creates slack.

Are your runs straight / is this wrapping on a spool? Slack can be created if the overall length of the cable run changes as the height of the elevator changes. This is common when cable wraps on top and the pulley diameter changes or if the run between stages isn’t straight vertical and the angle between pulleys changes as you move.

posts.name: James Lyon
posts.cooked: It’s hard to understand what’s going on in the drawing, but I think the problem is that you are using polychord. It’s really not meant for this kind of stress. I would recommend replacing the cord with dyneema rope, it’s much better suited to this situation. This might be caused by something different but I can’t diagnose that with the information given.

posts.name: kuzey
posts.cooked: yes the system runs on a spool. would you reccomend if we switched to rope instead?

posts.name: Egem
posts.cooked: We are compressing the polycord with two plates like a sandwich.

posts.name: Paul Copioli
posts.cooked:
One of the biggest things people get wrong is to make certain the cords they are changing length are perfectly parallel to the travel of your elevator. If they are not then they will change length at a rate different than the elevator motion.

If they are not parallel to the elevator travel path then the rope is acting as the hypotenuse of a triangle will not change inch for inch with the elevator travel.

If you can’t visualize this then draw the triangle at your start of travel and at your end. Your travel amount will be siffferwnt that your rope travel due to Pythagorean theorem.

posts.name: James Lyon
posts.cooked: Understood, I highly encourage switching to rope; The polychord is just too elastic for this application

posts.name: Egem
posts.cooked: We discussed this (rope vs polycord) when we decided to build an elevator and searched the applications of it. It (polycord) seemed like doable from what we have seen but now you are telling me that we need to change it, so i am clueless here When we finished the build it was working, but over time the polycord lost it’s tension so you are probably true.

posts.name: Egem
posts.cooked:
Mike_Schreiber:

just relying on it being cut to the right length?

yes, and i now realised that we made a mistake.

posts.name: Mike Schreiber
posts.cooked:
Look for UHMWPE rope, 7/64 is common, but you can likely run smaller since you are running this on both sides (at least that’s what it looked like to me). I’ve had success with 1.7mm (650 breaking strength) when running 2 lines. Thinner stuff will stretch more, you’ll need to tension it after you run it a few times, but it’s way less than what you’ll see from polycord.

Ideally you have an up string and a down string that are tensioned independently so you can sync the two strings to have the same tension and the same bottom of travel, you can get away with one side being fixed and the other being tensioned, but it means you’re playing with string tension all the time. There are lots of COTS solutions for this.

I’ve also seen people do a very stiff spring in line at the attachment point on the carriage to help take up the slack. This spring needs to be stretched when you tie the cable so that it will keep tension on the cable as the elevator dynamics stretch the cable.

posts.name: Mike Schreiber
posts.cooked:
That picture helps a lot.

Your cascade run is not vertical so the tension in the cable is changing as you move up and down. Try to get the runs between stages as vertical as possible. This picture may help.

posts.name: Egem
posts.cooked: Thank you so much for the help, we will try to solve the problem tomorro according to these pictures.

posts.name: Paul Copioli
posts.cooked: I also suggest the thinner ropes. We have been using 1.2mm kite string from a local sailing shop for years with great success. It is light and extremely strong.

posts.name: Mike Schreiber
posts.cooked:
The number you want to look at is how much the total length of the cable changes between the down and up positions. Usually the angle will increase when you move to the up position which makes your overall path length longer and puts the cable under more tension. In general I wouldn’t be too worried about 0.5 degree. Your runs look very straight, but you took the screenshot from the bottom, your worst case angle is usually when the pulleys are closest together.

Here’s a relatively not straight run and you can see it only changes by a few thousandths. This small amount impacts the tension a lot. That’s why it’s good to build some type of spring tensioner in.

image 867×1013 42 KB image 507×932 36.1 KB

image 867×1013 42 KB

image 867×1013 42 KB

posts.name: Kenta Vanderpool
posts.cooked:
Would that also explain a desync between the middle stage and carriage in a two-stage elevator? We had the same problem that you explained how to solve but we’re also seeing that when we run our elevator up and down, every cycle slightly offsets the stages from each other.

Basically, every time we go up and down, the carriage relative to the middle stage stays the same but the middle stage relative to the bottom/its initial position gets farther.

Very strange…

posts.name: Paul Copioli
posts.cooked:
In a continuous elevator the middle stage floats. If your friction is low then usually gravity will pull that middle stage down but not always. If it bothers you enough you can just put a light constant force spring holding the middle stage down from the first stage.

We don’t do this because the floating stages don’t bother us.
